inputs:
Q: A farmer had a goose that laid golden eggs every day. The farmer became very rich, but he was not satisfied with the goose laying only one egg per day. He thought to himself that if he could get all the golden eggs at once, he would become even richer. So, he killed the goose and cut it open, only to find nothing inside. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
  choice: Greed often overreaches itself.
  choice: It is better to be safe than sorry.
  choice: One good turn deserves another.
  choice: You cannot make an omelette without breaking eggs.
A:
targets: Greed often overreaches itself.
multiple_choice_targets: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Greed often overreaches itself.
It is better to be safe than sorry.
One good turn deserves another.
You cannot make an omelette without breaking eggs.

inputs:
Q: A fox saw a crow sitting on a branch of a tree with a piece of cheese in its beak. The fox, wanting the cheese for himself, flattered the crow by saying how beautiful she looked and how sweet her voice sounded. The crow, pleased with the compliments, opened her beak to sing, dropping the cheese which the fox quickly grabbed and ran away with. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: A friend in need is a friend indeed.
  choice: All that glitters is not gold.
  choice: Flattery will get you nowhere.
  choice: Look before you leap.
  choice: Pride goes before a fall.
A:
targets: Flattery will get you nowhere.
multiple_choice_targets: A friend in need is a friend indeed.
All that glitters is not gold.
Flattery will get you nowhere.
Look before you leap.
Pride goes before a fall.

Q: A lion, who was the king of the jungle, called all the animals to a meeting and asked them to bring him one animal each as a tribute. The fox, who was known for his cunning, brought the lion a sheep with a bell around its neck. When the lion asked why the sheep had a bell, the fox replied that it was so that the lion could hear the sheep coming from far away and catch it easily. The lion was pleased with the gift and let the fox go without any punishment. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: A stitch in time saves nine.
  choice: Cunning often outwits strength.
  choice: He who hesitates is lost.
  choice: Necessity is the mother of invention.
  choice: You cannot have your cake and eat it too.
A:
targets: Cunning often outwits strength.
multiple_choice_targets: A stitch in time saves nine.
Cunning often outwits strength.
He who hesitates is lost.
Necessity is the mother of invention.
You cannot have your cake and eat it too.

Q: A group of frogs were traveling through the woods when two of them fell into a deep pit. The other frogs gathered around the pit and saw how deep it was, telling the two frogs that there was no hope for them to escape. However, the two frogs ignored their comments and tried to jump out of the pit with all their might. The other frogs continued to tell them to give up, but one of the frogs eventually made it out of the pit, while the other one did not. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again.
  choice: It is better to be safe than sorry.
  choice: Misery loves company.
  choice: Out of sight, out of mind.
  choice: The grass is always greener on the other side.
A:
targets: If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again.
multiple_choice_targets: If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again.
It is better to be safe than sorry.

  choice: All that glitters is not gold.

inputs:
Q: A lion, who was feeling old and weak, decided to retire from his position as king of the jungle. He called all the animals together and asked them to suggest a successor. The monkey, who had an eye for opportunity, suggested himself, saying: "I am the cleverest of all animals, I can do anything." The lion laughed at him and said: "You? You are not fit to be king. You are just a jester." The elephant then stepped forward and offered himself as a candidate, but the lion refused him, saying: "You are too big and clumsy. You would never be able to catch your prey." One by one, all the animals presented themselves, but none were deemed suitable by the lion. Finally, a little mouse came forward and said: "I may be small, but I have a brave heart. I will do my best to protect the jungle and all its inhabitants." The lion was impressed by the mouse’s courage and appointed him as his successor. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Size doesn't matter.
  choice: A good leader listens to everyone.
  choice: Pride goes before a fall.
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
  choice: The greatest truths are the simplest.
A:
targets: Size doesn't matter.
multiple_choice_targets: A good leader listens to everyone.
Actions speak louder than words.
Pride goes before a fall.
Size doesn't matter.
The greatest truths are the simplest.

Q: A man was walking in the forest when he saw a fox that had lost its legs. Feeling sorry for the animal, he took it home and cared for it as if it were his own pet. One day, the man went out to run some errands, leaving the fox alone in the house. When he returned, he found that the fox had chewed off all the leather straps of his best shoes. Furious, he threw the fox out of the house and into the street. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: A leopard cannot change its spots.

Q: A crow, who was very thirsty, found a pitcher with some water at the bottom. However, the water level was too low for the crow to reach it with her beak. She tried to push the pitcher over, but it was too heavy. After thinking for a while, she picked up some pebbles with her beak and dropped them one by one into the pitcher. As more and more pebbles fell into the pitcher, the water level rose until it was high enough for the crow to drink. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Necessity is the mother of invention.
  choice: Where there’s a will, there’s a way.
  choice: A stitch in time saves nine.
  choice: You can’t judge a book by its cover.
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
A:
targets: Where there’s a will, there’s a way.
multiple_choice_targets: A stitch in time saves nine.
Actions speak louder than words.
Necessity is the mother of invention.

inputs:
Q: A wolf, who was very hungry, saw a lamb drinking from a stream. He decided to eat the lamb and approached her, saying: "How dare you muddy the water that I am drinking from?". The lamb replied: "I’m sorry, sir, but the water flows from you to me, so it’s impossible for me to muddy it.". The wolf then accused the lamb of insulting him the previous year, but the lamb replied: "I wasn’t even born last year.". The wolf, realizing he had no excuse to eat the lamb, attacked her anyway and devoured her. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Might makes right.
  choice: The end justifies the means.
  choice: Evil deeds will not go unpunished.
  choice: The law serves the strong.
  choice: The weak are meat, the strong do eat.
A:
targets: The weak are meat, the strong do eat.
multiple_choice_targets: Evil deeds will not go unpunished.
Might makes right.
The end justifies the means.
The law serves the strong.
The weak are meat, the strong do eat.

Q: A lion was once sleeping in the jungle when a mouse started running up and down his body just for fun. This disturbed the lion’s sleep, and he woke up quite angry. He was about to eat the mouse when the mouse desperately requested the lion to set him free. "I promise you, I will be of great help to you someday if you save me." The lion laughed at the mouse’s confidence and let him go. One day, while the lion was hunting, he got caught in a hunter’s trap. Unable to free himself, he filled the forest with his angry roar. The mouse heard the lion’s roar and quickly found him trapped. The mouse then ran around gnawing on the ropes that bound the king of the jungle. Eventually, the mouse managed to set the lion free. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: A stitch in time saves nine.
  choice: Slow and steady wins the race.
  choice: United we stand, divided we fall.
  choice: Little friends may prove great friends.
  choice: Every cloud has a silver lining.
A:
targets: Little friends may prove great friends.
multiple_choice_targets: A stitch in time saves nine.
Every cloud has a silver lining.

Slow and steady wins the race.
United we stand, divided we fall.

She tried everything she could think of to get hold of the water, but all her efforts were in vain. At last, she hit upon a clever plan.   choice: Necessity is the mother of invention.

Q: A hare was making fun of the tortoise one day for being so slow. "Do you ever get anywhere?" he asked with a mocking laugh. "Yes," replied the tortoise, "and I get there sooner than you think. I’ll run you a race and prove it." The hare was much amused at the idea of running a race with the tortoise but agreed to the challenge. The fox was to be the umpire of the race. As the race began, the hare raced way ahead of the tortoise, just like everyone thought. The hare got to the halfway point and could not see the tortoise anywhere. He decided to take a quick nap, as he had plenty of time to win the race. When he woke up, he realized that the tortoise was almost at the finish line. He ran as fast as he could, but he could not catch up in time to win. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
  choice: Haste makes waste.
  choice: Slow and steady wins the race.
  choice: The early bird catches the worm.
  choice: You cannot judge a book by its cover.
A:
targets: Slow and steady wins the race.
multiple_choice_targets: Actions speak louder than words.
Haste makes waste.
Slow and steady wins the race.
The early bird catches the worm.
You cannot judge a book by its cover.

Q: A wolf who had a bone stuck in his throat hired a crane for a large sum of money to put her head into his mouth and draw out the bone. When the crane had extracted the bone and demanded the promised payment, the wolf, grinning and grinding his teeth, exclaimed: "Why, you have surely already had a sufficient recompense, in having been permitted to draw out your head unharmed from the mouth and jaws of a wolf." What is the moral of this story?
  choice: A bad workman always blames his tools.
  choice: All that glitters is not gold.
  choice: Do not trust a stranger.
  choice: Never trust a flatterer.
  choice: You cannot have your cake and eat it too.
A:
targets: Never trust a flatterer.
multiple_choice_targets: A bad workman always blames his tools.

inputs:
Q: A man and his son were once going with their donkey to market. As they were walking along by its side, a countryman passed them and said: "You fools, what is a donkey for but to ride upon?" So, the man put the boy on the donkey and they went on their way. But soon they passed a group of men, one of whom said: "See that lazy youngster, he lets his father walk while he rides." So, the man ordered his boy to get off, and got on himself. But they hadn’t gone far when they passed two women, one of whom said to the other: "Shame on that lazy lout to let his poor little son trudge along." Well, the man didn’t know what to do, but at last, he took his boy up before him on the donkey. By this time, they had come to the town, and the passers-by began to jeer and point at them. The man stopped and asked what they were scoffing at. The men said: "Aren’t you ashamed of yourself for overloading that poor donkey with you and your hulking son?" The man and boy got off and tried to think what to do. They thought and they thought, till at last, they cut down a pole, tied the donkey’s feet to it, and raised the pole and the donkey to their shoulders. They went along amid the laughter of all who met them until they came to Market Bridge when the donkey, getting one of his feet loose, kicked out and caused the boy to drop his end of the pole. In the struggle, the donkey fell over the bridge, and his forelegs being tied together, he was drowned. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.
  choice: It is better to be safe than sorry.
  choice: One man's meat is another man's poison.
  choice: Pride goes before a fall.
  choice: Where there is smoke, there is fire.
A:
targets: Pride goes before a fall.
multiple_choice_targets: Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.
It is better to be safe than sorry.
One man's meat is another man's poison.
Pride goes before a fall.
Where there is smoke, there is fire.

So the man ordered his boy to get off, and got on himself. But they hadn’t gone far when they passed two women, one of whom said to the other: "Shame on that lazy lout to let his poor little son trudge along." Well, the man didn’t know what to do, but at last he took his boy up before him on the donkey. By this time they had come to the town, and the passers-by began to jeer and point at them. Q: A hare ridiculed the short feet and slow pace of the tortoise. The tortoise challenged the hare to a race, which the hare accepted. The hare ran down the road for a while and then paused to rest. He looked back at the tortoise and cried out: "How do you expect to win this race when you are walking along at your slow, slow pace?" The hare stretched himself out alongside the road and fell asleep, thinking: "There is plenty of time to relax." The tortoise walked and walked, never ever stopping until he came to the finish line. The animals who were watching cheered so loudly for Tortoise that they woke up the hare. The hare stretched and yawned and began to run again, but it was too late. Tortoise had already crossed the finish line. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
  choice: Haste makes waste.
  choice: Slow and steady wins the race.
  choice: The early bird catches the worm.

inputs:
Q: A farmer had a horse that he loved very much. One day, the horse ran away and the farmer’s neighbors came to console him. “What bad luck,” they said. But the farmer replied, “Good luck, bad luck, who knows?” A few days later, the horse returned with a herd of wild horses. The neighbors came to congratulate him. “What good luck,” they said. But the farmer replied, “Good luck, bad luck, who knows?” Later, the farmer’s son was riding one of the wild horses when he fell off and broke his leg. The neighbors came to console him. “What bad luck,” they said. But the farmer replied, “Good luck, bad luck, who knows?” A few weeks later, the army came to the village to recruit all able-bodied young men for the war. The farmer’s son was exempted because of his broken leg. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Every cloud has a silver lining.
  choice: Don’t count your chickens before they hatch.

Q: A group of frogs were traveling through the woods when two of them fell into a deep pit. When the other frogs saw how deep the pit was, they told the two frogs that there was no hope left for them. However, the two frogs decided to ignore what the others were saying and they proceeded to try and jump out of the pit. Despite their efforts, the group of frogs at the top of the pit were still saying that they should just give up. Eventually, one of the frogs took heed of what the others were saying and he gave up, falling down to his death. The other frog continued to jump as hard as he could. Once again, the crowd of frogs yelled at him to stop the pain and just die. He jumped even harder and finally made it out. What is the moral of this story?

Q: A hare was once boasting about his speed in front of the other animals. “I have never yet been beaten,” said the hare, “when I run at full speed, no one is faster than me.” The tortoise said quietly, “I accept your challenge.” “That is a good joke,” said the hare. “I could dance around you all the way.” “Keep your boasting till you’ve won,” answered the tortoise. They agreed on a route and started off the race. The hare shot ahead and ran briskly for some time. Then seeing that he was far ahead of the tortoise, he thought he’d sit under a tree for some time and relax before continuing the race. He sat down and soon fell asleep. The tortoise overtook him and soon finished the race, emerging as the undisputed champion. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
  choice: Slow and steady wins the race.
  choice: The early bird catches the worm.
  choice: There is no substitute for hard work.
  choice: Where there’s a will, there’s a way.
A:
targets: Slow and steady wins the race.

Q: A wolf was out of luck and hadn’t eaten for days. As he was walking through the forest, he saw a lamb drinking water from a stream. The wolf wanted to eat the lamb but knew that the lamb would run away if he approached him directly. So, he decided to trick the lamb. “How dare you make the water muddy so I can’t drink it!” shouted the wolf. “I’ll teach you a lesson.” “Please don’t kill me,” begged the lamb. “I’m not making the water muddy, sir. You are drinking downstream from me.” “Don’t argue with me,” replied the wolf. “You’re going to pay for what you’ve done.” And with that, the wolf pounced on the lamb and ate him up. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
  choice: Honesty is the best policy.
  choice: Revenge will hurt the avenger.
  choice: Slow and steady wins the race.
  choice: Where there’s a will, there’s a way.

targets: Revenge will hurt the avenger.

inputs:
Q: A man and his son were once going with their donkey to market. As they were walking along by its side, a countryman passed them and said, “You fools, what is a donkey for but to ride upon?” So the man put the boy on the donkey and they went on their way. But soon they passed a group of men, one of whom said, “See that lazy youngster, he lets his father walk while he rides.” So the man ordered his boy to get off, and got on himself. But they hadn’t gone far when they passed two women, one of whom said to the other, “Shame on that lazy lout to let his poor little son trudge along.” Well, the man didn’t know what to do, but at last he took his boy up before him on the donkey. By this time, they had come to the town, and the passers-by began to jeer and point at them. The man stopped and asked what they were scoffing at. The men said, “Aren’t you ashamed of yourself for overloading that poor donkey with you and your hulking son?” The man and boy got off and tried to think what to do. They thought and they thought until at last they cut down a pole, tied the donkey’s feet to it, and raised the pole and the donkey to their shoulders. They went along amid the laughter of all who met them until they came to a bridge, when the donkey, getting one of his feet loose, kicked out and caused the boy to drop his end of the pole. In the struggle, the donkey fell over the bridge and his forelegs were broken. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: All that glitters is not gold.
  choice: Don’t count your chickens before they’re hatched.
  choice: He who tries to please everyone pleases no one.
  choice: Necessity is the mother of invention.
  choice: You can’t make an omelet without breaking eggs.
A:
targets: He who tries to please everyone pleases no one.
multiple_choice_targets: All that glitters is not gold.
Don’t count your chickens before they’re hatched.
He who tries to please everyone pleases no one.
Necessity is the mother of invention.
You can’t make an omelet without breaking eggs.

Q: A hare was making fun of the tortoise one day for being so slow. "Do you ever get anywhere?" he asked with a mocking laugh. "Yes," replied the tortoise, "and I get there sooner than you think. I’ll run you a race and prove it." The hare was much amused at the idea of running a race with the tortoise, but agreed to the challenge. The fox was to be the umpire of the race. As the race began, the hare darted almost out of sight at once, but soon stopped and decided to take a nap. "How can you go to sleep when you know you are so far ahead?" he thought. Meanwhile, the tortoise kept going slowly but steadily, and, after a time, passed the place where the hare was sleeping. But the hare slept on very peacefully; and when at last he did wake up, the tortoise was near the goal. The hare now ran his swiftest, but he could not overtake the tortoise in time. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: Slow and steady wins the race.
  choice: United we stand, divided we fall.
  choice: Every cloud has a silver lining.
  choice: A stitch in time saves nine.
  choice: Little friends may prove great friends.
A:
targets: Slow and steady wins the race.

Q: A wolf was out of luck and hadn’t eaten for days. As he was walking through the forest, he saw a lamb drinking water from a stream. The wolf wanted to eat the lamb but knew that the lamb would run away if he approached him directly. So, he decided to trick the lamb into coming closer. "Hey you!" said the wolf. "Why are you muddying the water that I am drinking?" "I’m sorry," said the lamb. "But the water is flowing from you to me, not from me to you." "You’re lying," replied the wolf. "Last year you insulted me." "That’s impossible," said the lamb. "I wasn’t even born last year." "Well," said the wolf, "if it wasn’t you, then it was your father." "My father is dead," said the lamb. "Then I guess I’ll have to eat you," said the wolf as he pounced on the lamb. What is the moral of this story?

  choice: United we stand, divided we fall.

  choice: Might makes right.

Q: A hare was boasting about how fast he could run when he saw a tortoise walking slowly along. He challenged the tortoise to a race, and the tortoise, being confident in his own abilities, accepted. They agreed on a route and started off the race. The hare ran down the road for a while and then paused to rest. He looked back at the tortoise and cried out, "How do you expect to win this race when you are walking along at your slow, slow pace?" The hare stretched himself out alongside the road and fell asleep, thinking, "There is plenty of time to relax." The tortoise walked and walked, never ever stopping until he came to the finish line. The animals who were watching cheered so loudly for Tortoise that they woke up Hare. The Hare stretched, yawned and began to run again, but it was too late. What is the moral of this story?

  choice: Pride goes before a fall.
  choice: A stitch in time saves nine.
  choice: You can't make an omelette without breaking eggs.

The lamb replied, "I am sorry, sir, but I am drinking downstream from you, so the water is flowing from you to me, not the other way around." The wolf was not convinced and said, "Well, then last year you insulted me." The lamb replied, "I wasn’t even born last year."   choice: A guilty conscience needs no accuser.

Q: A man and his son were once going with their donkey to market. As they were walking along by its side, a countryman passed them and said, "You fools, what is a donkey for but to ride upon?" So, the man put the boy on the donkey and they went on their way. But soon they passed a group of men, one of whom said, "See that lazy youngster, he lets his father walk while he rides." So, the man ordered his boy to get off, and got on himself. But they hadn't gone far when they passed two women, one of whom said to the other, "Shame on that lazy lout to let his poor little son trudge along." Well, the man didn't know what to do, but at last he took his boy up before him on the donkey. By this time, they had come to the town, and the passers-by began to jeer and point at them. The man stopped and asked what they were scoffing at. The men said, "Aren't you ashamed of yourself for overloading that poor donkey with you and your son?" The man and boy got off and tried to think what to do. They thought and they thought, till at last they cut down a pole, tied the donkey's feet to it, and raised the pole and the donkey to their shoulders. They went along amid the laughter of all who met them until they came to Market Bridge, when the donkey, getting one of his feet loose, kicked out and caused the boy to drop his end of the pole. In the struggle, the donkey fell over the bridge, and his forelegs being tied together, he was drowned. What is the moral of this story?
  choice: You can please some of the people all of the time, and all of the people some of the time, but you can’t please all of the people all of the time.
  choice: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
  choice: Actions speak louder than words.
  choice: Better safe than sorry.
  choice: Don't put all your eggs in one basket.
A:
targets: You can please some of the people all of the time, and all of the people some of the time, but you can’t please all of the people all of the time.
